data.body:
Bhagavad Gita As It Is - Chapter 8 verse 20

paras tasmāt tu bhāvo 'nyo
'vyakto 'vyaktāt sanātanaḥ
yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu
naśyatsu na vinaśyati

paraḥ—transcendental; tasmāt—from that; tu—but; bhāvaḥ—nature; anyaḥ—another; avyaktaḥ—unmanifest; avyaktāt—from the unmanifest; sanātanaḥ—eternal; yaḥ—that; saḥ—which; sarveṣu—all; bhūteṣu—manifestation; naśyatsu—being annihilated; na—never; vinaśyati—annihilated.

TRANSLATION
Yet there is another nature, which is eternal and is transcendental to this manifested and unmanifested matter. It is supreme and is never annihilated. When all in this world is annihilated, that part remains as it is.

PURPORT
Kṛṣṇa's superior spiritual energy is transcendental and eternal. It is beyond all the changes of material nature, which is manifest and annihilated during the days and nights of Brahmā. Kṛṣṇa's superior energy is completely opposite in quality to material nature. Superior and inferior nature are explained in the Seventh Chapter.

October 27, 2007 - Budapest - Bhaktivedanta College Lecture #2  - English/ Hungarian
data.body: Bhaktivedenta College is a fully accredited, four-year college, fully sponsored by the Hungarian Government. It is located directly in the center of Budapest in a very prestigious part of the city. More than one-hundred sixty students are enrolled in the college, some of whom are weekly attending classes and are taking courses on Bhagavad-gita, Srimad Bhagavatam, The Nectar of Devotion, The four Vedas, The Six Goswamis, Sanskrit, and many other subjects related to Gaudiya Vaisnavism. When the students complete their four years of study, they are given degrees in "Vaisnava Theology" which can then be used for further studies, positions, or simply as an additional degree for their own advancement in academic studies. All of the teachers of the college are full-time practitioners of Krsna consciousness and are fully certified to teach their respective courses. Most of the students are enrolled in correspondence courses, and once every two weeks, on Saturday, they attend a lecture at the college to review their studies from the previous two weeks. Approximately fifty percent of the correspondence students and those attending daily classes are comprised of members of the Budapest congregation and are in some way connected with devotees although not all of them are practitioners of Krsna consciousness. However the other fifty percent of the students have no connection with Krsna consciousness other than through their enrollment with the college. Many of them come simply out of interest in Eastern Theology and Eastern Traditions. Once every month, the college holds a "Bhakti Club" program which is voluntarily attended by the students. There is usually a guest speaker or sometimes one of the teacher's will speak on the subject of Bhakti Yoga from the Bhagavad-gita. Niranjana Swami's October 1st lecture at the Bhaktivedanta College was one such gathering. This lecture given on October 27th was attended by approximately 80-100 students, most of them coming for their once-every-two-week, review-study on the fourth chapter of Bhagavad-gita.
